prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
A Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, champion has lost his title following accusations of unacceptable conduct. Yan Chenglong is under investigation for reportedly using a communication device akin to anal beads to cheat. The 48-year-old has been deprived of his title and prohibited from participating in tournaments for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) states that they cannot substantiate the cheating allegations against Yan.

Xiangqi has long enjoyed widespread popularity in Asia.

Following his victory in a national tournament on Hainan Island last week, Yan Chenglong is said to have consumed alcohol with friends in his hotel room. Subsequently, he allegedly damaged hotel property and breached public order and decency by defecating in the bathtub, according to the CXA's statement.

Rumors circulating online suggest Yan cheated using anal beads fitted with wireless transmitters to exchange signals. The CXA clarified that, at present, they cannot verify these claims.

As a consequence of his inappropriate behavior, Yan has been stripped of his title and banned from competition for a year. The CXA did not disclose the amount of prize money forfeited by Yan, but Xiangqi tournaments typically award winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), as reported by AFP.

Yan Chenglong, a renowned Chinese chess (Xiangqi) player, has been stripped of his title and barred from participating in tournaments for a year due to allegations of unacceptable conduct. According to reports, during a celebration following his win at a national tournament on Hainan Island, Yan damaged hotel property and breached public order and decency by defecating in the bathtub.

Additionally, rumors have surfaced online, claiming Yan cheated using communication devices resembling anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to exchange signals. However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) has not been able to substantiate these allegations.

Xiangqi, a popular pastime in Asia, has enjoyed widespread acclaim. The CXA stated that no concrete evidence has been provided to prove Yan's involvement in cheating.

The 48-year-old champion has been investigated for his inappropriate behavior, which led to the loss of his title and exclusion from competition. The CXA did not disclose the exact amount of prize money Yan forfeited, but it is common for Xiangqi tournaments to award winners with tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), as reported by AFP.

Furthermore, rumors have emerged online suggesting Yan utilized communication devices akin to anal beads, outfitted with wireless transmitters, to exchange illicit signals during games. Nonetheless, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) has yet to establish the veracity of these allegations.

Xiangqi, a beloved pastime in Asia, has garnered significant recognition. The CXA has stated no substantial evidence has been presented to implicate Yan in cheating.
